post0.title: P4 4/28 Lists Overview
post0.content: Overview . Teach about lists and dictionaries. . Subtopics on the lesson . Data Structures including List, Dictionaries, 2D arrays and Iteration (Big Idea 3). Teach these concepts by visualization. . Building Simulation/Interaction using Lists and Iteration | Storing List and Dictionary content in Databases | . Lesson Plans . Doing two lessons on what lists and dictionaries are and how to use them in databases. . Talk about vocabulary used throughout the lesson, Code segments to run and debug | Create lists and dictionaries | Show simulations | . Plans for Hacks . Create a list and a dictionary and compare the two. | . Grading . 0.2 for notes on the lesson | 0.3 for the creation of the list | 0.3 for the creation of the dictionary | 0.1 for the comparison | Extra 0.1 for creating a dictionary/list, iterating through it with a use inputed value, and giving an output which is dependent on the input (similar to the playlist maker) | .

post1.title: Dictionaries
post1.content: Ordered Dictionaries . Iterates over keys and values in the same order that the keys were inserted | If an entry is deleted and reinserted, then it will be moved to the end of the dictionary | Specially designed to keep its items ordered | Useful in situations where the order of insertion is important and when you need to process data in a specific order | If the order of the data is important, an ordered dictionary is the better choice | . How to create an ordered dictionary? . Import¬†OrderedDict¬†from¬†collections | Create an empty ordered dictionary by instantiating¬†OrderedDict¬†without providing arguments to the constructor | Add key-value pairs to the dictionary by providing a key in square brackets ([]) and assigning a value to that key. | Print the ordered dictionary | Iterate over the items in the ordered dictionary | Regular Dictionaries . Mutable; can add, remove, and modify key-value pairs after they have been created | Used to store data values in key:value pairs | Can be iterated over using loops | If order is not important, a regular dictionary may provide better performance | . How to create a regular dictionary? . Create a variable name which will be the name of the dictionary | Assign the variable to an empty set of curly braces {} | Create a dictionary with the dict() OR empty curly brackets | Hacks . Make a venn diagram about ordered dictionaries and regular dictionaries .

post2.title: Title
post2.content: import sqlite3 from sqlite3 import Error def create_connection(db_file): conn = None try: conn = sqlite3.connect(db_file) return conn except Error as e: print(e) return conn def create_table(conn, create_table_sql): try: c = conn.cursor() c.execute(create_table_sql) except Error as e: print(e) def main(): database = 'instance/songs.db' sql_create_songs_table = """ CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS songs ( genre text NOT NULL, artist_name text NOT NULL, track_name text NOT NULL, duration_ms integer NOT NULL, tempo integer NOT NULL ); """ conn = create_connection(database) # create table if conn is not None: # create books table create_table(conn, sql_create_songs_table) else: print("Error! cannot create the database connection.") if __name__ == '__main__': main() . # Populate import sqlite3 as sq import pandas as pd connection = sq.connect('instance/songs.db') # Create a cursor object curs = connection.cursor() student = pd.read_csv('files/songs.csv') # Write the data to a sqlite db table student.to_sql('songs', connection, if_exists='replace', index=False) # Run select sql query curs.execute('select * from songs') # Fetch all records # as list of tuples records = curs.fetchall() # Close connection to SQLite database connection.close() . import sqlite3 conn = sqlite3.connect('instance/songs.db') cursor = conn.cursor() cursor.execute("ALTER TABLE songs DROP COLUMN popularity") cursor.execute("ALTER TABLE songs DROP COLUMN acousticness") cursor.execute("ALTER TABLE songs DROP COLUMN danceability") cursor.execute("ALTER TABLE songs DROP COLUMN energy") cursor.execute("ALTER TABLE songs DROP COLUMN instrumentalness") cursor.execute("ALTER TABLE songs DROP COLUMN key") cursor.execute("ALTER TABLE songs DROP COLUMN liveness") cursor.execute("ALTER TABLE songs DROP COLUMN loudness") cursor.execute("ALTER TABLE songs DROP COLUMN mode") cursor.execute("ALTER TABLE songs DROP COLUMN speechiness") cursor.execute("ALTER TABLE songs DROP COLUMN time_signature") cursor.execute("ALTER TABLE songs DROP COLUMN valence") conn.commit() cursor.close() conn.close() . import sqlite3 def selectby_genre(genre): conn = sqlite3.connect('instance/songs.db') cursor = conn.cursor() results = cursor.execute("SELECT track_name FROM songs WHERE genre = ?", (genre,)) print(results) cursor.close() conn.close() # def selectby_artist(): # def selectby_artist(): x = 'Movie' selectby_genre(x) . <sqlite3.Cursor object at 0x7f29e05ffce0> . def select_by_genre(): import sqlite3 conn = sqlite3.connect('instance/songs.db') c = conn.cursor() user_input = input("Enter genre:") # replace with actual user input c.execute("SELECT track_name, artist_name, genre FROM songs WHERE genre = ? ORDER BY RANDOM() LIMIT 5;", (user_input,)) results = c.fetchall() for row in results: print(row) conn.close() print("") def select_by_artist(): import sqlite3 conn = sqlite3.connect('instance/songs.db') c = conn.cursor() user_input = input("Enter artist name:") # replace with actual user input c.execute("SELECT track_name, artist_name, genre FROM songs WHERE artist_name = ? ORDER BY RANDOM() LIMIT 5;", (user_input,)) results = c.fetchall() for row in results: print(row) conn.close() print("") select_by_genre() select_by_artist() . .
